selected_quotes: Association Between #TVviewing and #physicalactivity in 10-year Old Brazilian Children.

citation.abstract:
Studies have found an association between television (TV) viewing and physical activity levels. The purpose of this study was to examine the association between TV viewing and physical activity in 10-year old Brazilian children.
The sample consisted of 485 children. Self-reported TV viewing on weekdays and weekends was assessed by questionnaire. An Actigraph GT3X+ accelerometer was used to monitor the range of physical activity intensities (including moderate-to-vigorous physical activity; MVPA), sedentary behavior (SB) and steps/day over 7 days.
Daily MVPA was highest among children viewing TV <1 hour/day (69 min) compared to children viewing 1-2 hours/day (61 min), 3-4 hours/day (55 min) and ≥5 hours/day (59 min) on weekdays (p=0.0015). Differences in MVPA were not observed across TV categories on weekends. The prevalence of reaching 60 min/day of MVPA and 12,000 steps/day on weekdays was significantly greater in children viewing ≤2 hours/day (51.7% and 23.5%, respectively) compared to those viewing >2 hours/day (38.6%, p=0.0058; and 15.1%, p=0.0291, respectively). There was no difference in SB across TV viewing categories.
Time spent in MVPA and the frequency of meeting MVPA guidelines were significantly higher among children viewing ≤2 hours/day of TV on weekdays compared to those viewing more.
citation.journal: Journal of Physical Activity and Health
citation.title: Association Between Television Viewing and Physical Activity in 10-year Old Brazilian Children.

author.name: Johanna Hänggi
author.description: PhD researcher. Interested in media use in children and how it affects children's physical activity and sedentary behavior. Is all screen-time sedentary?
